Headlines.Headline: Twitter Plans $1.5 Billion Debt Offering-- 2nd Update
Headlines.Author: Yoree Koh

PARAGRAPH.#text: Twitter Inc. plans to raise as much as $1.5 billion in the social-media company's first sale of debt to support its growing business. The San Francisco company said it is offering convertible bonds in two chunks of $650 million, according to a securities filing on Wednesday. One will mature in five years and the other in seven. The company said it would allow initial buyers to purchase an additional $100 million on each piece. Convertible notes pay interest like a bond but can be converted into shares in some cases.

Headlines.Headline: Fiji Military Chief Says Syrian Militants to Release Peacekeepers -- 2nd Update

PARAGRAPH.#text: SUVA, Fiji--Fiji's military chief said Wednesday that Syrian insurgents have agreed to release 45 United Nations peacekeepers later this week without conditions. His comments couldn't be immediately verified by either the U.N. or the Nusra Front. Fijian Brig. Gen. Mosese Tikoitoga said Fiji had received word from U.N. headquarters in New York that the Nusra Front would release the men in the coming days without any conditions or demands. He didn't give a precise timetable or specifics of how the handover would take place.

Headlines.Headline: Fighter Jets Investigate Small, Unresponsive Plane Over Atlantic
Headlines.Author: Jon Ostrower

PARAGRAPH.#text: A small private plane became unresponsive while flying over the eastern U.S. on Friday, causing the military to send fighter jets to investigate. A spokesman for the Jamaican military said the plane crashed in the ocean north of the Caribbean island, according to the Associated Press. The North American Aerospace Defense Command said it dispatched two F-15 fighter aircraft late Friday morning after the plane stopped responding to calls from air-traffic control. The aircraft, a Daher-Socata TBM-900 single-propeller plane that can carry up to six adults, was flying from Rochester, N.Y., to Naples, Fla.

Headlines.Headline: In Washington, the 'Me Wall' Still Trumps the Selfie
Headlines.Author: Elizabeth Williamson

PARAGRAPH.#text: WASHINGTON--In a wood-paneled office in the tony Willard Hotel complex near the White House, lobbyist Rick Hohlt works surrounded by himself. Smiling down from every wall of the elegant suite and winding down the hallway are photographs of Mr. Hohlt posed with presidents, political candidates, European leaders and Pope John Paul II. This is Mr. Hohlt's "me wall," as some call it, built over four decades of government work and tens of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions. The collection contains not a single selfie.

PARAGRAPH.#text: MADRID--Spain's Defense Ministry said a Spanish missionary priest who has tested positive for the Ebola virus has landed in Spain on a flight from Liberia. A message on the ministry's official Twitter account said the medically equipped Airbus 310 landed at 0615 GMT Thursday at Torrejon air base, close to Madrid. The priest, Miguel Pajares, will be treated at a hospital in the Spanish capital. His assistant in Liberia, Spanish national Juliana Bohi, was also brought back but she isn't infected.

Headlines.Headline: Jailed Slovenia's Ex-Prime Minister Comes to Inaugural Parliament Session
Headlines.Author: Leos Rousek

PARAGRAPH.#text:
A recently jailed ex-Prime Minister Janez Jansa Friday received a brief pass to leave his low-security prison to take part in the inaugural session of the country's parliament, of which he's a member after winning a seat in the July election.
Mr. Jansa, the leader of the opposition Slovenian Democratic Party, or SDS, began to serve his two-year sentence for bribery late June. He has denied wrongdoing and has appealed against his sentence to the country's Supreme Court, insisting that his trial was political. Before reporting to his prison he was allowed to register as a parliamentary candidate and launch his party's election campaign.

Headlines.BodyHeadline: Jailed Slovenia's Ex-Prime Minister Comes to Inaugural Parliament Session

PARAGRAPH.#text: Among the companies with shares expected to actively trade in Wednesday's session are Twitter Inc. TWTR, Sprint Corp. S, Humana Inc. HUM and Hess Corp. HES. Twitter reported Tuesday its second-quarter revenue more than  doubled and the company saw an uptick in user growth, signaling its efforts to make the short messaging service more appealing to the masses may be bearing fruit. Shares surged 23.8% to $47.74 in premarket trading. Sprint said it swung to a profit in its fiscal first quarter, as its operating expenses declined and it narrowed its loss of the most lucrative contract customers.

Headlines.Headline: Sprint Tries a Facebook-Only Plan
Headlines.Author: Ryan Knutson

PARAGRAPH.#text: For about $12, Sprint will soon let subscribers buy a wireless plan that only connects to Facebook. For that same price, they could choose instead to connect only with Twitter, Instagram or Pinterest--or for $10 more, enjoy unlimited use of all four. Another $5 gets them unlimited streaming of a music app of their choice. The plan, offered under the company's Virgin Mobile brand of prepaid service, comes as wireless carriers are experimenting with ways to make wireless Internet access more affordable for the poorest consumers by offering special deals on slices of the Web.

Headlines.BodyHeadline: Sprint Tries a Facebook-Only Plan

Marek Switajewski said Unipetrol was increasing its stake in Ceska Rafinerska, the country's largest refinery, and wouldn't sell its Kralupy facility despite surplus capacity at its oil refining unit. His comments throw cold water on a proposal by Czech Finance Minister Andrej Babis, made this spring, that the Czech state should purchase Unipetrol's refinery in the town Kralupy.

Headlines.Headline: Twitter Operating Chief Ali Rowghani Resigns -- Update
Headlines.Author: Michael Calia

PARAGRAPH.#text: Twitter Inc. said executive Ali Rowghani had stepped down from his role as the social network's chief operating officer, according to a regulatory filing Thursday. Mr. Rowghani will continue to be employed by the company, acting as an adviser to Chief Executive Dick Costolo, Twitter said. The company said it doesn't intend to hire a replacement to fill the operating chief role and that other members of the management team will assume its responsibilities. "Goodbye Twitter. It's been an amazing ride, and I will cherish the memories," read a tweet from Mr.

Headlines.Headline: Twitter Considers Executive Reshuffle, Cuts Operating Chief Duties - Report
Headlines.Author: Barbara Kollmeyer

PARAGRAPH.#text: Twitter Inc. TWTR is considering a reshuffle of its top executives, Recode reported Wednesday, citing sources close to the company. The online social networking and microblogging service has reduced some duties of Chief Operating Officer Ali Rowghani, who had been given the task of beefing up the company's consumer offerings and bringing in more users. Lackluster growth and product innovation, along with the fact Mr. Rowghani recently sold a large amount of stock, are causing the company to consider whether it even needs a chief operating office, those sources said.

Headlines.Headline: Two Women Kidnapped at Malaysia Dive Resort Are Freed: Police
Headlines.Author: Jason Ng

PARAGRAPH.#text: Malaysia's police chief said two women from China and the Philippines who were abducted from a remote diving resort have been freed. The women, identified as Gao Hua Yuan, 29 years old, a student from Shanghai, and 40-year-old Marcy Dayawan, a Philippine worker at the resort, were kidnapped April 4 by seven armed men at the Singamata Adventures Reef and Resort off Malaysia's state of Sabah. The area borders the southern Philippines, and is an active base for armed gangs including Abu Sayyaf, a terrorist organization linked to al-Qaeda that has frequently carried out robberies and kidnappings, including of tourists at diving resorts, for more than a decade.

Headlines.Headline: Despite Data Thefts, the Password Endures
Headlines.Author: Danny Yadron

PARAGRAPH.#text: Fernando Corbató didn't intend to unleash havoc when he helped create the first computer password at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the early 1960s. "It's become kind of a nightmare," says the 87-year-old retired researcher. "I don't think anybody can possibly remember all the passwords." Passwords are a bane to computer and smartphone users and a security threat to companies. On Wednesday, eBay Inc. urged its 145 million users to change their passwords because of a data breach. But if the past is a guide, few people will heed the warning.
